EPID 592 Spatial Epidemiology Zoom Session 1

Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

![](../images/epid_logo.png){.absolute bottom=0 right=50 width="400" height="100"} ## Goals for today - Answer any burning üî• questions about Week 1 and the class in general. - Digest and synthesize Week 1 content. - Think ahead to Week 2. ## Agenda - Who am I and why do I care so much about spatial epidemiology (~10m) - Week 1 questions and concerns (~25m) - Zoom fatigue ü•±/bio break (5m) - Week 1 concept-mapping (~30m) - Looking ahead to Week 2 (~5m) ## Who am I & what do I do? :::{.columns} :::{.column width=40%} - Infectious disease epidemiologist. - Trained as a social epidemiologist/sociologist (UM Sociology PhD 2011). - Research group focused on health geography and transmission modeling. - Infection inequity is the theme that motivates most of our work. ::: :::{.column width=60%} ![Me: Basically interested in how infectious diseases get from one person or place to another.](../images/zelner_headshot.jpg) ::: ::: ## Got a first-hand feel for what it's like to think spatially about an emerging public health event {.imgslide} Cumulative incidence of COVID-19 in Michigan 3/2020-3/2022 (from [covidmapping.org](https://www.covidmapping.org)) ## Spatial models are just mental models formalizing the relationships between spatial arrangements and disease outcomes
[M]ental models and empirical data keep each other in check - [Sir Peter Medawar] described them respectively as the ‚Äòbride‚Äô and ‚Äògroom‚Äô of science ‚Äî and scientific progress in any discipline occurs by the back-and-forth dialogue between their two ‚Äòvoices‚Äô.‚Äù
[From Greenhalgh 2021: *Miasmas, mental models and preventive public health*](https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rsfs.2021.0017) ## Week 1 Recap We have covered a lot of territory: - What is spatial epidemiology, anyway? - What is the role of mapping üó∫Ô∏è in spatial epid? - Spatial patterns of health outcomes as the output of complex socio-epidemiological systems ‚öôÔ∏è. ## What questions or ideas did this week's readings, videos, and assignments spark ‚ú®? Open up this [google doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1tRzmusTtqK51G5I2jHhDeFpT_Kh54Vw5nLwfaXrOFhY/edit?usp=sharing) and add your answer to each of the following questions: 1. In 1-2 sentences, how would you describe what spatial epidemiology is? 2. What did you find most surprising or interesting from the course this week? 3. What left you confused or would be helpful to clarify? ```{r} library(countdown) countdown(minutes = 10, warn_when = 120, seconds = 0, play_sound=TRUE) ``` # Break! ```{r} library(countdown) countdown(minutes = 5, warn_when = 60, seconds = 0, play_sound=FALSE) ``` ## Bringing the threads üß∂ together with a mind-mapping exercise :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} - Much like a geographic map, a mind-map uses distance/connections to help us think about the relatedness of concepts. - Start with a central problem or question and branch out from there. - Goal is to use this exercise to clarify connections between readings from this week and set an agenda going forward. ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![Example mind map from my son's preschool ca. 2017](../images/mind_map_example.png){width=60%} ::: ::: ## Lets take some time to map out these ideas and their connections. - Going to break into 4 groups - Spend 5-7m on each of four questions as a group in a breakout room. - Goal is to synthesize material from the week and build on each other's understanding. - At the end, we will briefly review all of the maps and pick out major themes. ## Building your mind maps ![Motivating questions are available in [this Miro board](https://miro.com/app/board/uXjVPKV4LZA=/?share_link_id=51250319196)](../images/20221025131943.png) ## Next Week :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} - Why focus on a historical outbreak in a course on spatial epidemiology? - Detailed examination of interacting social, environmental and biological forces. - Shows the long arc of learning behind a dramatic and important event in epidemiological history. - Shows how spatial analysis is at the center of much epidemiological practice even if we don't always notice it. ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![John Snow and the 1854 London Cholera outbreak](../images/snow_cholera_map.jpg) ::: :::
